bboxes.raw_text:
A warrant has been issued in
Wednesdays shooting of Colin
Beals, IS, of Laveen.


The warrant charging assault
with a deadly weapon was is
sued for the arrest of George
Willie Davis, %, in the court
of Justice of the Peace AL ].
Flood.


Officers said Davis shot Colin
Beals of Laveen outside a tavern
at 1919 W. Buckeye Road with
out cause.


Beals, a contractor, was talk
ing to an employe when he was
shot, Witnesses told police.

DENVER-C ontinental Airlines
must hire Marion D. Green, a
Negro, as a pilot, Denver Dis
trict Judge Neil Koran has ruled.


Green's employment had been
ordered in January 1859 by the
Colorado Anti-Discrimination
Commission. The u. S. Supreme
Court affirmed the decision last
year.


Green had claimed that the air
line refused to hire him because
of his race. He is a former
Air Force captain.

Continental AirIines


To Hire Negro Pilot

Seven is considered a lucky
number and Mrs. Katherine Hick-
man of Flagstaff is one of the
luckiest persons in the state.


On the seventh day of the
seventh month at 7 pm. she
delivered fraternal twins, her
seventh boy weighing seven
pounds. and her seventh girl,
also a seven FOUNDER. That's
IT sevens.


Mrs. Hickman and her husband,
Sanders. started their family %
years ago when Bobbie was born.
Bobbie is employed by
Motor ola's Semiconductor Prod
ucts Division.


The Hickman family includes;
Pat 20. Addie = Is. Cissy and
Tim 10 0he first set of twins
and the first in a series of boys).
Sanders is, Roy l3. James
IL, Donnie 10, Robby 7,
Cathy S, Sandra 2-l/2.
and the lucky "sevens" Daryl
and Carol Lynn.


AS if those odds aren't enough,
here's the clincher Bobbie
Hickman Hannah has daughter
of her own, Tracy. who at the
age of 8 is older than two aunts
and an uncle.

PHILADELPHIA Six white
boys we're charged in the fatal
beating of Steven Gaines, l5year
old Negro lad.


Gaines died two days after he
and two companions we're at
tackled by the white youths be-
hind the Museum of Art. His
death was attributed to
fractured skull.


One youth charged in the death,
James Williams, l6, was caught
Immediately after the beating.
He named his other friends who
range from ages IA to 10.

6 White Boys
Charged In
Negro Lads Death

Secretary Interior Stewart L. Uda End from right
pauses folwng address In which Mr. Udal dedicated the
Washington of Frederick Douglass pre-Cil War
abolitonist, national shrine.


U.s. Government by the national
Association Clubs nc whose National Pesi
dent Dr. L. Cragg Detroit Michigan seen at LETT Mrs.
historic which
Columbia The Interior Secretary NCWC
Czen- the principal speaker at the awards
convention Denver
July August l.


from left received Y
award the Hendrix Of the Washing
PRman, junior associate in The Moss H. HENDRIX
Organization handling CocaCoa

Charles T. Chuck Williams.
Schenley's new Negro vice presi-
dent, served with distinction as a
fighter pilot in World War II
in the famed cred Tail" squadron
in Europe and won many medals.
In his student days. an outstand-
ing athlete and was the first
Negro elected to the student coun-
ell of his school.


He was born in Nogales, Ari-
iona and educated at the Univer-
sity of Southern California at
Los Angeles. When war was de-
clared, Williams volunteered for
the Air Force. He was the only
Negro in a large class to take
the qualifying examination for the
Air Force. Hf-~-


Recently appointed vice pres
ident of Schenley Distillers Co.,
Williams is known among his as
sociates as ga nice guy who gets
things DONE"


Joining Schenley in 1851 as
salesman and advanced to special
sales representative, brand de-
velopment manager, assistant di-
vision manager and assistant ma
tional sales manager worked his
way to a vice presidency.


MIR. Williams zeal for his job
was never diminished, according
to his associates. He is just
another example of Negro who
has opened the door of success
SO that Negro youth will know
when you are prepared color is
no barrier in attaining the highest
positions in the world of work."


GLOBAL PORTRAITS

last year.


Four complains charged prices
were increased and two were
lodged because of refusal of SER
vice.


Mrs. F. Peralta, cafe CO. owner
denied the charges and said they
we're trying to make trouble for
her again.

CORE Charges FL Rey Cate
Owner With Discrimination

Trial for Mrs. Ramona Tapia
Moreno, %, has been reset for
Aug. 3. She is accused of first
degree murder in the knitting
death of Grady Holly, rs, last
Sept. l6, at drive-in market at
94o W. Buckeye.


Mrs. Moreno, of 800 w. Grant,
has been undergoing mental OBJ
servation at Arizona State
Hospital, and Charles B. Tanner,
defense counsel, asked for the
delay.

The Congress of Racial
Equality filed the first complaint
covered by the citys new public
accommodations ordinance.


Six charges of discrimination
were filed against the Ell Rey
Cafe, o22 S. Central, the site
of the city s first demonstrations

Making plans for future activities of the Girl Scouts in the
Chapel AE Church members the conference
the church last week.


includes Mrs. L. K. Williams Roy Nixon, Mrs. Betty
Colbert and Mrs. Ocie Boysaw.


group Crystal Townsend conference director
Mesdames Leatha Campbell Delphi McBrayer
leader Leanna Tucker leader Rev. L. Williams Tanner
Chapel and Stenkamp Girl Scouts Council
representative.


Investtuture also held.

ON July %, 1862, a lean and byoodi'g faced
man sat doaOn at his desk and completed the
first draft of a document which Mould innaed-
lately affect millions of Negroes ensL0Ued IN
nation beset by great ciUil war: 1t wos not
uutil January of the following year that Pres
ident Lincoln formally announced the Enamel
patton Proclamation Which freed more than 20
million men, women and children of African
descent.


Last year throughout the country hundreds OF
Obsey FRANCES we're held cOmanaemaOYuting the
passing of the century after this document had
been signed. Too often our efforts are pm
pointed tOwaYd one program or one ceIe6Tu-
tion with this in nind the editors OF this
newspaper present this special edition to
observe the first year Of the second century
after the Emancipation Proclamation.


We feel that the progress Of the American
Negro should be he1ulded throughout the year.
should be included in the textbooks and each
child should be aWoYe Of the past, present and
future of those 20 millions whose toYetatheTs
once wore chains.


Rather than lament the past ne must look to
the wears ahead. Let us hope that this lOlst
year oUilI provide greater goals and achseUe-
,uents than ne haze ever dreamed OF.

lot YEARS AFTER THE
EMANCIPATION PROCLAMATION
